Assessing for underlying causes and contributing factors
Assessing the severity of urinary incontinence

subChapters.htmlHeader: Who should not receive an antimuscarinic?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not prescribe an antimuscarinic drug to people with [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]: 
    • Myasthenia gravis.
    • Significant bladder outflow obstruction or urinary retention.
    • Severe ulcerative colitis, toxic megacolon.
    • Gastrointestinal obstruction, intestinal atony, paralytic ileus, pyloric stenosis.
  • In addition:
    • Do not prescribe oxybutynin (immediate release) to older women who may be at higher risk of a sudden deterioration in their physical or mental health [NICE, 2019].
  • Prescribe antimuscarinic drugs with caution to people with [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]: 
    • Acute myocardial infarction, arrythmias (may worsen), cardiac insufficiency, cardiac surgery, congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, conditions characterised by tachycardia.
    • Autonomic neuropathy.
    • Diarrhoea, gastro-oesophageal reflux disease or hiatus hernia with reflux oesophagitis.
    • Hypertension.
    • Hyperthyroidism.
    • Susceptibility to angle-closure glaucoma.
    • Pyrexia.
    • Ulcerative colitis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What dose of antimuscarinic should I prescribe?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Table 1. Licensed doses of antimuscarinic drugs for urinary incontinence. 

Antimuscarinic preparationsDose
Oxybutynin immediate-release tablets (2.5 mg, 3 mg, and 5 mg)5 mg two or three times a day, increasing to a maximum of 5 mg four times a day. In elderly women, a starting dose of 2.5 mg or 3 mg twice a day is recommended. Oxybutynin (immediate release) should not be given to older women who may be at higher risk of a sudden deterioration in their physical or mental health.
Oxybutynin prolonged-release tablets (Lyrinel XL®,5 mg and 10 mg)5 mg daily, increasing to 10 mg daily after 7 days if necessary. Total daily dose should not exceed 20 mg. There should be an interval of at least 7 days between any dose changes.
Oxybutynin transdermal patch (Kentera®, releasing 3.9 mg of oxybutynin per 24 hours)One 3.9 mg transdermal patch applied twice weekly (every 3 to 4 days).
Darifenacin prolonged-release tablets (Emselex®, 7.5 mg and 15 mg)7.5 mg daily, increasing to 15 mg daily after 2 weeks if necessary.
Fesoterodine prolonged-release tablets (Toviaz®, 4 mg and 8 mg)4 mg daily, increasing to 8 mg daily if necessary.
Propiverine hydrochloride tablets (Detrunorm® 15 mg)15 mg once or twice a day, increased if necessary to a maximum of 15 mg 3 times a day. Maximum dose 30 mg daily if eGFR† is less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2. 
Propiverine hydrochloride capsules modified release (Detrunorm® XL 30 mg)30 mg once daily. Maximum dose 30 mg daily if eGFR† is less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2. 
Solifenacin immediate-release tablets (Vesicare®, 5 mg and 10 mg)5 mg daily, increasing to 10 mg daily if necessary.
For people with severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance 30 mL/min or less), moderate hepatic impairment (Child–Pugh score of 7–9), and if treated with a potent inhibitor of CYP 3A4 (such as ketoconazole, itraconazole, nelfinavir, and ritonavir): do not exceed 5 mg daily.
Tolterodine immediate-release tablets (Detrusitol®, 1 mg and 2 mg)2 mg twice a day. Reduce to 1 mg twice a day if adverse effects are troublesome.
For people with impaired liver function or severe renal impairment (eGFR† 30 mL/min/1.73m2 or less) prescribe 1 mg twice a day.
Tolterodine prolonged-release capsules (Detrusitol XL® 4 mg)

4 mg daily.
In people with impaired liver function the recommended dose is 2 mg once daily. 

This formulation is not suitable for people with severe renal impairment (eGFR† less than 30 mL/minute/1.73m2) and should be avoided.

Trospium chloride tablets (20 mg)20 mg twice daily. Reduce dose to 20 mg once daily or 20 mg on alternate days if eGFR† is 10–30 mL/minute/1.73 m2. Avoid in severe hepatic impairment.
Trospium chloride prolonged-release capsule (Regurin XL® 60 mg)60 mg once daily. This formulation is not suitable for people with renal impairment or severe hepatic impairment. 
† estimated glomerular filtration rate

[ABPI, 2013; ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2014a; ABPI, 2015a; ABPI, 2015b; ABPI, 2015c; ABPI, 2018a; ABPI, 2018b; ABPI, 2019a; ABPI, 2019b; ABPI, 2019c; ABPI, 2019d; ABPI, 2019e; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019; NICE, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What adverse effects of antimuscarinics should I be aware of?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Common adverse effects of antimuscarinic drugs include [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]: 
    • Dry mouth.
    • Constipation.
    • Dizziness.
    • Drowsiness.
    • Headache.
    • Nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia.
    • Palpitations, tachycardia.
    • Urinary disorders.
    • Vision disorders.
    • Skin reactions, flushing.
  • More rarely encountered adverse effects include angioedema or confusion (more common in older people) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019] .
• For information on drug interactions for individual antimuscarinic drugs, see the manufacturers' Summaries of Product Characteristics (www.medicines.org.uk) or the British National Formulary.
